p: The colonization rates that were recorded sixty days after inoculation with R. irregularis were lower compared to those reported by other authors [53], [54]. Low colonization rates are usually attributed either to excess in P [26] and/or to root exudation of inhibitory compounds before the formation of appressoria [55], [56]. The hypothesis postulating exudation of inhibitory compounds was not supported since appressoria were visible at sixty days. In relation to P concentration, although its value in the sandy loam soil used for mesocosms was low, its concentration could be different after sterilization because of NH 4 + release [57], which could affect rhizosphere pH and consequently P availability. Moreover, the changes in pH affect the intensity of AM root colonization [58].
